intro: Acaena lucida var. distorta, commonly known as the distorted sunflower, is a variant of the sunflower species native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its distinctive, twisted and elongated flower heads, which give it its common name. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that are clustered in dense, spherical inflorescences. Its leaves are typically narrow and hairy, with a rough texture. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and subalpine regions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena lucida var. distorta is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the northern and central regions of the country. This variety grows in a variety of habitats, including forests, shrublands, and coastal areas. It is commonly associated with the North Island and parts of the South Island. The plant is adapted to the temperate climate and diverse soils of New Zealand.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena lucida var. distorta was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. This plant has since become naturalized in several regions of the country. It is commonly found in coastal and lowland areas, particularly in the North Island. Its introduction has raised concerns due to its potential to invade native ecosystems.
